Chapter 4 Summary

Introduction

This chapter discusses the rules and regulations from Section 1 of the All India Fire Tariff, observed as good practices. It also details fire insurance policies, premium rating principles, and rates for various risks.

A. Policies

1. General Rules and Regulations

  • Standard Fire and Special Perils Policies (SFSP) are issued with optional add-ons.
  • Policies must include a proposal form, schedule, endorsements, warranties, and clauses.
  • Separate amounts must be shown for:
    • Buildings
    • Machinery and Accessories
    • Stock and Stock-in-Process
    • Furniture and other contents
  • RSMD and STFI perils can be excluded from inception.

2. Types of Policies

  • Valued Policies: For items with no ascertainable market value.
  • Long-Term Policies: Minimum term of 36 months for house/flat owners.

3. Partial Insurance

  • Policies cannot cover specific portions of a building (except plinths and foundations).
  • Separate insurance is allowed for parts owned by different owners.

4. Short-Period Rates

Rates for policies under 12 months range from 10% for 15 days to 85% for 9 months.

5. Policy Cancellation

  • At Insured's Option: Premium retained as per short-period scale.
  • At Insurer's Option: Pro-rata refund applies.

6. Mid-Term Cover Adjustments

  • Additional perils can be added mid-term with extra premium, starting 15 days post-payment.
  • Sum insured can increase (pro-rata basis) or decrease (short-period scale).

B. Fire Insurance Premium Rating

1. Principles of Premium Rating

  • Rates depend on:
    • Physical hazards.
    • Grouping risks into homogeneous categories.
    • Loss experience of groups.
    • Discrimination principle for individual risks.

2. Classification of Risks

  • Principal groups include:
    • Simple Non-Manufacturing Risks: e.g., offices, hospitals, shops.
    • Manufacturing Risks: Based on processes and materials.
    • Godowns and Warehouses: Classified by stored goods' hazard levels.

C. Types of Risks and Rates

1. Simple Risks

Includes dwellings, offices, restaurants. Rates vary for hazardous and non-hazardous goods.

2. Manufacturing Risks

  • Rates are provided for ~205 industries. Examples:
    • Brickworks: 1 per mille.
    • Breweries: 2 per mille.
    • Battery Manufacturing: 2.25 per mille.

3. Utilities (Outside Industrial Risks)

  • Examples and rates:
    • Boiler House: 1.5 per mile.
    • Dam: 1 per mile.
    • Pump House (Others): 2.5 per mile.

4. Storage Risks

  • Goods classified into:
    • Category I: Slightly combustible or inert.
    • Category II: Moderately hazardous.
    • Category III: Highly hazardous.
  • Rates vary based on type and location (godown, open storage).

5. Tanks and Gas Holders

Rates depend on liquid/gas type and flashpoints. For example:

  • Liquids flashing below 32°C: 3.50 per mile.
  • Gas holders (non-inert gases): 5 per mile.

D. Additional Discounts and Provisions

  • Claims Experience Discount: Based on incurred claims ratio:
    • Up to 5%: 1.5% discount.
    • 5–10%: 10% discount.
    • 10–15%: 5% discount.
  • Fire Extinguishing Appliances Discount:
    • Hand Appliances & Hydrant Systems: 5%.
    • Comprehensive systems: 10%.
  • Computation Sequence:
    1. Basic rate.
    2. Reductions for excluded perils.
    3. Additions for hazardous constructions.
    4. Discounts for claims experience and fire appliances.
